author: SteveL-MSFT
body:

# PR Summary

POSIX shells have a `-l` switch to indicate it is a login shell which will process profiles.  However, PowerShell by default already loads the profile and requires `-noprofile` to explicitly not load it.  To make pwsh compatible with other tools (like VSCode) that expects a `-l` switch, the change is to add `-loadprofile` aliased as `-l` so that it doesn't complain about that switch which is a no-op since we load the profile by default.

Also sorted the switches alphabetically in the code.

## PR Context

Fix https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/3600

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Based on new RFC I think this should be `-Login` or `-LoginShell` parameter.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @iSazonov the problem with calling it `-LoginShell` is that it doesn't make any sense for Windows.  I don't think Linux users care about the long form as they would just use `-l`.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Linux users will very confused to see long form in docs - they expect "login" but get another. The current solution looks like a hoax. I think we could discuss this in your RFC.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @iSazonov bring up as an issue in the RFC, we can still change while in Preview

title: Add support for `-l` to pwsh so that it is compatible with POSIX shell expectations
